sp.p: Thou'rt undone, should'st thou trust to the Promises and Oathes of this Seducer; they are meere Cobwebs to catch silly Flies: Besides, Betty, to admit such Visits, and take Presents, and to delight in the Amorous Conversation, and dalliance of these Periwig-men, is a Sin (Betty) and a great one.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: No sure; A Sin is a black ugly thing: but this is so pleasing, and sweet; And when one means no hurt—

sp.speaker: Sir Salom.
sp.p: I tell you, 'tis a Sin, unless Marriage take away the offence.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Say you soe? Then pray, Sir, Marry me out of hand.

sp.speaker: Sir Salom.
sp.p: Yes, Betty, I intend to Marry thee; and I have put all things in readiness for it.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: But, When will you do it?

sp.speaker: Sir Salom.
sp.p: To morrow morning.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: To morrow morning?

sp.speaker: Sir Salom.
sp.p: Without faile: I see you are mightily pleas'd.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Yes indeed: I shall be extreamly obliged to you, and hugely satisfyed in him.

sp.speaker: Sir Salom.
sp.p: Him? What him?

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Why, him, we spoke of.

sp.speaker: Sir Salom.
Betty.
sp.p: Why; What must I doe?

sp.speaker: Sir Salom.
sp.p: You shall shut the door on the Face of him, and then if he knocks, you shall send that after him out of the Window, which shall coole the heate of his Passion.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: How shall I be able to do that? He is so kind and so handsome—

sp.speaker: Sir Salom.
sp.p: What? D'ee make a difficulty of it, when I command it? Betty, no more words; before I stirr from hence I'le see you do it my self. I know we shall have him quickly here. Come along with me, I find you want Instruction yet.

div.stage: Enter Sir Arthur, and his two Foot-boys.

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: Nay, Sarrah; by Martial-Law I'le ha' thee hang'd for giving a false Allarum, and putting me in such a disorder, as I have hardly yet recovered.

sp.speaker: S. Foot-boy.
sp.p: Truely (Sir) I took 'em to be the Monsters you spoke of.

sp.speaker: Sir Arthur.
sp.p: Did you so? And where were your Eyes (Puppy? a Pox o'your fears, that made 'em see double: Of all Men living, I hate these Cowardly Rogues.

sp.speaker: T. Foot-boy
sp.p: apart. Then I'le be sworne, my Masters no self-lover.

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: This is the time too of Old Waryes Assignation. And I Vow, 'tis all I can do, to rally my Forces against my Onsett on Mrs. Iulia.

sp.speaker: T. Foot-boy.
sp.p: This, Sir, was the hour by him appointed to meet you in these walkes.

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: Go tell him, Boy, that I am here, and stay for him.

sp.speaker: T. Foot-boy.
sp.p: Here they are, Sir.

sp.speaker: Iulia.
sp.p: Have you no body, Sir, to offer me, but the most notorious Fool of the Town?

sp.speaker: Wary.
sp.p: Peace: Thou art a greater Fool then he, to refuse a man, that has a great deal of Mony, and little Witt; and so lose the opportunity of being sole Mistriss of a large Fortune. See, in what a submissive posture the Amorous Knight begs his admittance into your Favour? Nay, come up to him—Sir Arthur, here's my Daughter, and God send you good luck with her. Perhaps you'l find her a Coy Mistriss; but, let not that dishearten you; farewell; I'le leave you to your selves.

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p:
Come, Madam; now we are alone, you need not be ashamed to speak your mind freely to me: Be of good
Courage; I am kind-hearted, and can deny you nothing that you ask.

sp.speaker: Iulia.
sp.p: Sure, the Fool expects that I should Court him. [apart. Truly, Sir Arthur, I would fain ask you something; but, I am afraid, you are not good-Natur'd, nor a Man of your Word.

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: As I am a Gentleman, and a Knight—She's coming already—

sp.speaker: Iulia.
sp.p: But, What if you should deny me? you know, for a Woman to be refused, is the last misery that can befall her.

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: Alass, poor heart; I vow I take such pity o'thee, that there is no kindness, I would not do instantly for thee.

sp.speaker: Iulia.
sp.p: VVell (Sir) remember your promise: I ask you to forbear all manner of Courtship, or pretention to Marry me.

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: This is very pretty I faith: I know well enough, you say this now only to try me; I can't but laugh to think, how damnably you'd be mump'd, if I should take you now at your word.

sp.speaker: Iulia.
Sir Arth.
sp.p: So, so; y'are very pleasant: But, pray Madam, for a while give over Fooling, and be serious; Alass, I know y'are bashfull (as all young women are, or should be) and loth to come out with't: Therefore I'le take pitty o'you, and speak your mind for you; You'd fain have a Husband (VVould you not? and you'd be marryed to a man of Fortune, and good Parts, and be a Lady, (I know you would:) Then say no more, trouble your self no farther, you shall have all this, here's your Man, take him, and be thankful.

sp.speaker: Iulia.
sp.p:
Is there any persecution like that of a [apart. Confident Fool. Sir Arthur, I confess y'are a Man of Fortune; but, I am not of Fortunes mind to dote upon you, as she has done: As for your good Parts, they are past my understanding; and for the Ladyship you talke of, pray keep it for
those, who are disposed to wear it for your sake, which I am resolved never to do.

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: What a perverse Woman is this?— [apart. Well, well, Madam; for all this, I'le not despair, but that you may come to your wits yet; In order whereunto I have this Letter to deliver you: Perhaps good Counsel may do much, pray persue it well; and afterwards let me know your Mind.

sp.speaker: Iulia.
sp.p:
I know the Hand: But; I cannot possibly imagine, how he should come to be the bearer of it— [apart.
Julia reads the Letter apart from Sir Arthur.
Madam, if your Fathers severity has stirred in you the same Melancholy humor, as in me, this Fool, whom I send for your Divertisement, may prove no unseasonable Present: But, there's another use to be made of him, much more important to me, and (I hope) to you; For, he's very proper to amuse your Fathers unquiet Suspitions of our Love, and to fill the Room of a Suitor, which might otherwise be taken up by some body of more danger: There can be no fitter Person, then he, to be deceiv'd himself, and to deceive others. I therefore leave him to your discreet management; for, in your Conduct and Affection, lie all the hopes and happiness of your humble Adorer Single.

Well, Single, since thou hast put me upon't, I'le act the part thou gav'st me, so to the Life, that thou shalt tremble at thine own disguise; and so by a wholsome severity I will at once punish thy jealous humour, and secure thy Love—Sir Arthur, come hither; What d'ee think this Letter Contains?

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: A great deal of Truth, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Iulia.
sp.p: Be you the Judge of that; take it, and read it.

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p:
Truly I am a modest man, and don't love to read my own Commendations: but, since you Command it—Hai, What's here?—This Fool—for your Divertisement—to be made use on—to amuse your Fathers—discreet Management:—O Traitor! there's not a
true word in it. Judge you, (Madam;) Am I a Fool? Am I a fit Person to deceive, or be deceived?

sp.speaker: Iulia.
sp.p: No, Sir Arthur: And, to let you see what part I take in the injury done you, this is the Answer, which (She tears it. I give to so malitious a Libel. 'Tis true, I am none of those, who can fall in love with a Man at first sight (which perhaps you may take unkindly at my hands)—

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: No indeed, not I.

sp.speaker: Iulia.
sp.p: But I am so much concern'd to see plain-dealing and honest simplicity abus'd, under the colour of Friendship, that I shall always side with the well-meaning-Party against the false underminings of Dissemblers.

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: What a happy man am I?

sp.speaker: Iulia.
sp.p: You are to know, that this Mr. Single has been a Pretender to me himself; and now he makes you his stalking-horse to drive the Game into his own Nets: But, go you immediately to him, and relate what y'ave seen me do, and heard me say; and tell him from me, that I have now taken a better man into his Room.

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: Let me alone; I'le tell him his own to some tune.

sp.speaker: Iulia.
sp.l: Since thou art doom'd to Poverty
By a Mad-fathers harsh Decree,
And since my Sentence is the same
From mine, if I admit thy Flame;
Single, 'twill just in me appear
To try well, what must cost so dear:
No Common test is fit to prove
The truth, and firmness of thy Love;
Since thou with nothing com'st to me,
And I leave all to follow thee.

sp.speaker: Pereg.
sp.p: Some way or other I am resolved to find out this woman, before your Father is Marryed to her: I must break, or delay the Match.

sp.speaker: Single.
sp.p: Your Labour will be fruitless. What can you do in so short a time? his Wedding is to Morrow.

sp.speaker: Pereg.
sp.p: I have all to day for it: And I'le do nothing, but watch him, and dog him from place to place, till I find out his hant.

sp.speaker: Single.
sp.p: Should you compass the seeing her, What will it avail? you may as soon Convert a Iew, as make him alter his Resolution.

sp.speaker: Pereg.
sp.p: But she may be Converted: For if she have Honour or Reason in her, 'twill be enough to tell her only the plain story of your Fathers Humor, and Injustice towards you. If she be void of both, I'le get some Wench or other to swear a Promise of Marriage with your Father: Rather then fail I'le pretend a Contract my self with his Mistriss; and so forbid the Banes. For, What is't I would not do to serve my Friend in such an Exigence?

sp.speaker: Single.
sp.p: In all your designs I see much of your kindness, but very little probability of success.

sp.speaker: Sir Arthur?
sp.p: I suppose you come immediately from your Mistriss. Well? Have you deliver'd my Letter?

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: Yes, Sir; I have deliver'd it.

sp.speaker: Single.
sp.p: And, I hope, it produc'd those good effects, which you have cause to thank me for.

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: O yes, Sir; I thank you most abundantly.

sp.speaker: Single.
sp.p: But, Have you not brought me an Answer?

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: Yes, I have an answer for you, but, 'tis by word of mouth.

sp.speaker: Single.
sp.p: How's this? Sure you mistake your self.

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: No, good Mr. Single; 'Tis you that mistake your self, and me too: For, I am no Fool (d'ee see;) And Mrs. Iulia cares not this for you. What say you now, Sir?

sp.speaker: Single.
sp.p: Either the Fool's run mad, or I shall—Sir Arthur, you are grown very misterious: Pray, tell me plainly, What did she say?

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: Then, to be plain, Sir, she said no better of you, then you Writ of me.

sp.speaker: Single
sp.p: apart. Was ever Man so cross-bit, and confounded by an Asse.

sp.speaker: Sir Arthur.
sp.p: Alass, poor Mr. Single! I find you are exteamly troubled: But, I scorn to be base; and, one good turn deserves another. Shall I write a Letter of Commendation for you to Mrs. Iulia? Ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Single.
sp.p: Y'are too sawcy: Give over fooling quickly, or I shall grow in earnest. Come, tell me her Answer; and, if you swerve one tittle from the Truth, I shall be worse to you, then a thousand Rivals.

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: Lord! Why are you so angry now? If Mrs. Iulia will be kind to me, Can I help it?

sp.speaker: Single.
sp.p: That it should be in the power of such a Worme to sting me thus!—Dispatch; What said she?

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: Good Lord! in what haste you are to hear ill News? I vow now, I can't help it: she read your Letter, and then gave it me to read (I need not tell you what was in't). When I had read it, she took it and tore it (without my bidding her) And said, That was the Answer she made to it: Withall, she bid me tell you, That she was now provided with a better Man to fill your room.

sp.speaker: Single.
sp.p: 'Tis false, She did not; She could not say so.

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: I thought what 'twould come too—Why, look'ee now, if you won't believe me, ask her.

sp.speaker: Single.
sp.p: Sir Arthur, This business must not pass so: I must be farther satisfy'd in the Truth of your relation, or I shall take a course, which I suspect may not be agreeable to your temper. Go instantly back, and let her know from me, that, when she sends such a Message by such an Embassadour, she ought to send her Credentials too: And I shall also advise you, for your own sake, to bring me a speedy account of this business.

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: Methinks you might take my word for a greater matter then this; But, you shall have your humour, and I'le go strait—Would I were well rid of him.

sp.speaker: Single.
sp.p: Where can Faith be found, if Iulia be false? Must Vertue it self degenerate to Trechery, and an Angel turn Devil to complete my unhappiness?

sp.speaker: Pereg.
sp.p: Come, come; All this may be nothing but a Trial of your Constancy; or some Stratagem of Love to amuse the froward suspicion of her old Father.

sp.speaker: Single.
sp.p: She could not shew that Fool my Letter, and tear it before his face, with any other design, but to abandon, and destroy me.

sp.speaker: Pereg.
sp.p: Be not so hasty to conclude her unfaithful, and your self unfortunate: For my part, I hold it impossible, that a Woman of Wit, who has always been constant to you, should on the sudden desert you for so despicable a Person, as your pretended Rival.

sp.speaker: Single.
sp.p: Ah, Peregreen! had but a nobler Object debauch't her from me, it would not have put such scorn upon my sufferings: But now I fall dishonourably by an infamous hand, and am expos'd at once to Ruine, and Contempt.

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: Now, Sir, I hope I have pleas'd you; I told her all that you said: And, she bid me tell you again, that, since you are so hard of belief, both she, and her Father will meet you in this place within this hour, to give you full satisfaction in the point: And so God b'wy.

sp.speaker: Single.
sp.p: Nay, but Sir Arthur; Pray, one word more with you. Come near.

sp.speaker: Sir Arthur.
sp.p: By no means, Sir; I am in haste; And my Mistriss will be angry, if I stay from her so long. Farewell.

sp.speaker: Single.
sp.p: So; Now I think my business is compleatly done: Nature and Love have both declar'd me their Enemy; whilst I am disinherited by my Father, and forsaken by my Mistriss. What have I left me, but to Court an honourable and speedy Death?

sp.speaker: Pereg.
sp.p: At least suspend your judgment, till you speak with Iulia. All this may still be a blind to cover, and secure your Love. You must not expect at first sight, to see the bottom of a Womans Pollicy in matters of this Nature: They manage such Affairs with a subtlety, and address beyond our reach.

sp.speaker: Single.
sp.p: Your excess of kindness makes you flatter my Misery with vain hopes.

sp.speaker: Pereg.
sp.p: You must not antedate your Misery by Despair; That will teach Fortune the way to ruine you: First hear what Iulia sayes; examine well her words, and her eyes; And then you may knowingly make a Judgment of your Case—I shall impatiently waite the success of this Assignation. In the mean time I must beg your leave to dispatch a Visit here close by to my little Betty; That being done, your Concerns shall be my whole Employment. Adieu.

sp.speaker: Single.
sp.p: Dear Peregreen, Farewell.
sp.l: Peregreen knocks at Mrs. Bettys Lodging,
Ralph looks out, and shuts the Door upon him.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: Stand off.

sp.speaker: Pereg.
sp.p: Hai dai! What's the meaning of this? I'le try a little farther; perhaps he mistook me for another.

div.stage: Ralph and Alice both look out.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: What would you have?

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.p: Here's nothing for you.

div.stage: They shut the Door upon him again.

sp.speaker: Pereg.
sp.p: They turne me away like a Beggar from the door! Now I am sure they saw me—Ralph, Alice—my pretty Rogues, Don't you know me? 'Tis I.

div.stage: Mrs. Betty from the Belcony throws down a Brickbat, and with it a Letter.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Betty.
sp.p: To all y'ave said, or have to say to me, this is my Answer.

sp.speaker: Pereg.
sp.p:
Does that hand persecute me too? she speaks in Thunder, and vanishes like Lightning—If this [He takes up the Brick. be your Answer, 'tis a weighty one; had it come home to me, 'twould have Silenc'd me for ever. 'Tis impossible that Betty should be so changed all o'the sudden, as to do this of her self; without
dispute Old Evans has been allarum'd, and is now himself upon the Guard: I must 'een draw off at present from the Enemies Quarters—What have we here? a Letter, For Mr Peregreen Woodland? good, or bad, I'le take it; but, this is no place to read it in.

div.stage: Ralph peeps out at the Door, and then looks back.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: The Bird is flown.

div.stage: Enter Sir Salomon, Mrs. Betty, Ralph, and Alice.

sp.speaker: Sir Salom.
sp.p: Most bravely perform'd of all hands; you Ralph, and you Alice did so well execute my Orders, that now I forgive you all your past-faults: And you, my dear Betty, are now restored to the place you formerly held in my affections; For know, that I am no less a Rewarder of Vertue, then a Punisher of Vice: I believe my Confident Lover will brag no more of this Adventure; The Brick-bat has dasht in pieces all his Designes. And now, Betty, learn from hence the necessity of a wise Conducter even for Innocence it self: Thou hadst been quite lost, and undone, had I not miraculously deliver'd thee from the Ambuscade, which was laid to ruine thee; but, for the future I hope, all of you are sufficiently instructed, how to behave your selves, should he renew his attempts again.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: We have our Lesson without book now; let him come when he will, and do his worst, I defie him.

sp.speaker: Sir Salom.
sp.p: But have a care you be not caught with his smooth Words, and fair Promises; What would you say to him now, if he should come to you, and cry, Ralph, honest Ralph, Wilt thou forget thy Friend? take a little pitty of me.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: No; y'are a Rogue.

sp.speaker: Sir Salom.
sp.p: Good: But thou Alice at least art so pretty and sweet, thou canst not be so hard-hearted.

sp.speaker: Allice.
sp.p: Y'are a Iack-straw.

sp.speaker: Sir Salom.
sp.p: Excellent! Alass, What hurt is there in the thing which I ask? I intended nothing but Honour and Vertue.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: Y'are a Cunning Catching Rascal.

sp.speaker: Sir Salom.
sp.p: Rarely well; Nay then, if you no compassion of me, I must die.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: The sooner the better.

sp.speaker: Sir Salom.
sp.p: Most incomparable? You know, I am none of those, who use to forget the Courtesies done 'em: I never leave a Service unrewarded: And, to give you a taste of my gratefull nature, Ralph, here's for thee to Drink; and Alice, here's to buy thee a laced Hancarcher; This is but a small earnest of what I intend.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: Am I a Man to be brib'd? stand off.

sp.speaker: Sir Salom.
sp.p: That's right.

sp.speaker: Allice.
sp.p: Get you out.

sp.speaker: Sir Salom.
sp.p: To the Life.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: Get you out.

sp.speaker: Sir Salom.
sp.p: As it should be.

sp.speaker: Allice.
sp.p: But presently then.

sp.speaker: Sir Salom.
sp.p: Mighty well? but now 'tis enough.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: Be gone then.

div.stage: [They both thrust him about more then ever.

sp.speaker: Sir Salom.
sp.p: Hold I say.

sp.speaker: Allice.
sp.p: We won't hold, you come to affront our Master Evans.

sp.speaker: Sir Salom.
sp.p: I tell you I am in earnest.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: So are we too: wee'l do what our Master bid us.

sp.speaker: Sir Salom.
sp.p: Give over, I say, or I'le break my Staff about your cares.

sp.speaker: Allice.
sp.p: Must we give over so soon?

sp.speaker: Sir Salom.
sp.p: How the Slaves have bruised me?

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: What say you now, Sir? Han't we done as we should do?

sp.speaker: Sir Salom.
sp.p: Extreamly well; only you were a little too slow of understanding to'rds the Last, and too quick in taking Mony at First.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: I Swear, I had quite forgot that part of my Lesson concerning Mony: But, since we were out, Shall we do it over again?

sp.speaker: Sir Salom.
sp.p: No: 'Tis enough.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: Speak but the word, and we are ready.

sp.speaker: Sir Salom.
sp.p: Y'ave done very fairly: ye may now withdraw, whil'st I talk a little in private with Betty. [Exit Ralph and Alice. Betty, methinks you are very silent; And yet that's a thing I like very well in a Woman, I know, poor heart, thy mind is troubled for the over-sight thou didst commit, not out of Malice, but through too much Innocence: But, Betty, be not dismay'd; thy Fault is forgiven, and forgot: and, for a testimony of it, to morrow I'le Marry thee.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: To Morrow, Sir? that's very soon.

sp.speaker: Sir Salom.
sp.p: How comes it to pass, that now 'tis too soon, when two hours ago you thought it hardly soon enough.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: I am grown more knowing since that time; For, you have given me so many Admonitions concerning the Duty of a Wife, that 'tis impossible for me to have 'em perfect so soon.

sp.speaker: Sir Salom.
sp.p: Thou shalt get them perfect by the practice of 'em: And, Betty, to let thee see, how my kindness is enlarged to 'rds thee, and to Crown all my other benefits heaped upon thee, take this Writing, and preserve it charily, for in this I make thee Mistriss of my whole Estate. Moreover, Betty, I'le tell thee a Secret, which thou little dream'st on; To morrow thou shalt be a Lady, and shalt have a place much above the Ranck of the Modern ones. And now, Betty, consider well, what gratitude you owe the Author of so much happiness— Did the rest of the World Marry at this prudent rate, we should not hear such loud Complaints of Wedlock-Fetters.
sp.l: Let foolish Men their Marriage-Fate deplore;
Whil'st I to Cupid his lost Eyes restore:
And all the Poyson from his Darts remove,
By teaching Wisdom in the School of Love.

div.head: The Fourth Act.

sp.speaker: Sir Salom.
sp.p: THis I must own to be the Fortunate Moment of my Life: For now the Harvest is come of my long ripening Designs, which call for the Sickle. I touch the very Center of Human Felicity, which lies in that Point, where expectation ends, and fruition begins. I am now beholding to the late Assaults and Dangers I have sustain'd, which add to the fullness of my Joy the Pleasure of Victory. That I could but see the Countenance of my defeated Rival since his Salutation with the Brickbat? What a Change shall I find in the briskness of his Humour?

sp.speaker: Pereg.
sp.p: Sir Salomon; I have been to waite on you at your Lodging; and have sought you farr and neer.

sp.speaker: Sir Salom.
sp.p: Good Mr. Peregreen, y' are heartily wellcome. Well; and how thrives Love? I suppose by this y' are in a fair possibility of enjoyment.

sp.speaker: Pereg.
sp.p: Faith, Sir, that's the very business I have to conferr with you: I know not how it comes to pass, but (to tell you truly) I have had some Traverses in my Affairs, since I last imparted them to you.

sp.speaker: Sir Salom.
sp.p: I protest, I'm extreamly sorry for it. Why What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Pereg.
sp.p: Without dispute, that watchfull Dragon, old Evans, smells the Powder, and stands upon his Guard to countermine all my Designs.

sp.speaker: Sir Salom.
sp.p: What reason have you to think so?

sp.speaker: Pereg.
sp.p:
I know it must so: For, I had absolutely gain'd those
two Animals, the Man, and Maid of the Family; and made them as tame, and obedient to all my purposes, as watch't-Hawkes; And now (all on the sudden) they are turn'd Haggard again, know me not, and repulse me with such rudeness, as if they had never seen my face, nor taken my Mony.

sp.speaker: Sir Salom.
sp.p: What ill luck's this? But how in the name of Wonder should this Evans come to the knowledge of your Design?

sp.speaker: Pereg.
sp.p: I know not what Devil of Jealousie has inspir'd him; But too sure I am, that he has me in the wind; For (not many houres since) going to visit my Betty, as I use to do, when I came to the House, and had one foot in, they shut the Door with violence upon me; and both Man and Maid cry'd out, VVhat make you here? here's nothing for you—

sp.speaker: Sir Salom.
sp.p: I vow, this was very hard usage; after they had taken your Mony too.

sp.speaker: Pereg.
sp.p: However, I venter'd to knock once more; and presently Betty her self came to the Belcony, and threw a huge Brickbat at me, telling me, That was her Answer to all I had to say.

sp.speaker: Sir Salom.
sp.p: A Brick-bat, say you? That was an odd Favour for a Mistriss to bestow on her Gallant: But, Did it hit you?

sp.speaker: Pereg.
sp.p: No; I had the good fortune to avoid the blow.

sp.speaker: Sir Salom.
sp.p: VVhat pitty 'tis, so hopeful a Design should be knock't oth' head with a Brick-bat?

sp.speaker: Pereg.
sp.p: Hold, Sir; for all this, ther's some life in't still: and, I believe, old Evans, who was the Engineer, that rais'd this Battery against me, will have no cause at last to brag of his Victory.

sp.speaker: Sir Salom.
sp.p: If the young VVench be o'your side, you may easily out-wit the old Man's Vigilance.

sp.speaker: Pereg.
sp.p: I don't question it; And, 'tis no small part of my satisfaction, to think, how this Jealous Coxcomb fooles himself into a security upon this imaginary Rout.

sp.speaker: Sir Salom.
sp.p: VVell, Sir;—How he frights me?

sp.speaker: Pereg.
sp.p:
Now you shall see, that Love is an equal Conqueror of Art, and Nature; First, in baffling all the subtlety, and stratagems
of that old Fox; And next, in making a cunning Pollititian of Innocent Betty.

sp.speaker: Sir Salom.
sp.p: VVhere will this end?

sp.speaker: Pereg.
sp.p: For she, being constrain'd by her Tyrant to give me this unwilling Repulse, at the same time under the shelter of that Brick-bat dropt a Letter at my Feet so full of sweetness, and unsophisticated-love, exprest with so much Innocence, and Modesty, that now I'm no less charm'd with the beauty of her Mind, then with the Loveliness of her Person.

sp.speaker: Sir Salom.
sp.p: I am relaps'd into Torment!—

sp.speaker: Pereg.
sp.p: Don't you admire this miraculous effect of Love, and readiness of wit in so ignorant, so unpractis'd a Creature? Methinks, you are not so affected with the strangeness of it, as the thing deserves.

sp.speaker: Sir Salom.
sp.p: O, yes; I'm unspeakably surpriz'd.

sp.speaker: Pereg.
sp.p: VVhen the Door was shut against me, and the bawling Servants houted at me, and the hand-granado was flung out to route the poor Lover, VVas not the Pollitick Conducter of this Stratagem all this while in a dainty Fooles-Paradice? Did he not act a pleasant Part in this Tragi-Comedy? VVhy don't you Laugh heartily at it?

div.stage: [Sir Salo. sq—ueezes out a forc'd Laughter.

sp.speaker: Sir Salom.
sp.p: I protest, I Laugh as heartily, as I can—How I'm worry'd by him!

sp.speaker: Pereg.
sp.p:
But, as you are my Friend, I must needs shew you her Letter; For, I believe, you never saw a more admirable piece in the kind: Do but hear it. [Peregrine Reads. VVhat shall I do? I must write my Thoughts to you, and yet I know not how to chuse words to express them: For I have been bred in such ignorance, that all the knowledge I have, is, that I want it. This makes me fearfull of saying any thing, least I should say, what I ought not. I know not what 'tis y' ave done to me, but I find, it goes to my very heart to use you as I am forc'd to do. Mr. Evans does often Preach to me, That all young men are Deceivers; and, that 'tis their Trade by fair promises to cheat VVomen of their Honour, and then forsake 'em. Pray tell me whether it be so or no. I have no Malice my self; and, should you deceive me, 'twould be ill done, and I'm confident 'twould kill me—
Was ever any thing so tender, and so ravishing? How her Wit and her Love flow from the clear Fountain of Nature, without the least tincture of Artifice? And, Is not this Evans a most unsufferable Beast to drown in ignorance and stupidity (as much as in him lies) so perfect a Soul, and so capable of the highest improvement?

sp.speaker: Sir Salom.
sp.p: Oh!

sp.speaker: Pereg.
sp.p: What ailes you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Salom.
sp.p: Nothing, but a Cold. Uh, uh, uh.

sp.speaker: Pereg.
sp.p: I must needs beg your assistance a little in this business: For, I am a stranger in Town, and you are the only person I confide in. Could you not acquaint me with some of the Neighbours thereabouts, where I might have access, to watch opportunities of speaking with my Mistriss?

sp.speaker: Sir Salom.
sp.p: No; I have not any acquaintance in that Quarter. Farewell.

sp.speaker: Pereg.
sp.p: Pray Sir, stay a little longer: The kindness of friends should be reciprocal. You have not told me any thing concerning the progress of your own Affairs: I suppose the Wedding holds for to morrow. I am resolv'd (notwithstanding the urgency of my own occasions) to prepare my self for it. But, Sir, Will you not grant me the favour to kiss the fair hands of your Lady before the Marriage?

sp.speaker: Sir Salom.
sp.p: It can't be: The time is short. God b'ye.

sp.speaker: Pereg.
sp.p: This good Sir Salomon has a strange Ague in his Nature: His Temper never holds the same for half an hour together. How pleasant, and well humor'd he was, when first we began our discourse; And after a while how sullen, and ill at ease he seem'd to be? Poor Single! I pity thy hard Fortune, in having such a Father.

sp.speaker: Sir Salom.
sp.p:
Is he gone at last?—Could any Devil, but he, be so skilfull in the Art of tormenting? Could any Devil, but she, have so much untaught Mallice born in her Nature? My Patience and my Wits will forsake me! I have publish'd my Wedding,
nam'd the Day, invited my Friends, and, Am I not finely provided with a Bride? I shall become the Discourse of every Coffy-house, be Libell'd, Lampon'd, Acted; and every Fool will think himself a Wit, when he talkes, and tells Stories of me—

div.stage: Sir Salomon takes several turnes upon the Stage, and takes no notice of Timothy, who follows him from side to side.

sp.speaker: Timothy.
sp.p: Sir, according to your appointment, all things are in readiness, as becomes your Quality, and the Solemnity of such a Wedding. The Taylor, Milliner, Semstress, and Periwig-Maker, for the setting forth your Person; And the Butcher, Polterer, Vintner, Confectioner, and Fruiterer, for setting forth the Feast, have all brought in their Provisions▪ But, there is such a tearing noise of Fidles▪ Drums, and Trumpets at your Lodging, to give your Worship Joy, that your whole Family are like Seamen in a Tempest, all bawling, and none hearing: They are His Majesties Trumpets, and His Grace the Lord Generall's Drums, What will your Worship be pleas'd I shall give them?—

sp.speaker: Sir Salom.
sp.p:
A Halter—How all Mankind conspires to torment me! Where shall I hide my head, [Timothy starts back.
and shelter my Person from the Scorn and Mockery of the World? Have I made it my business all my life to separate my self from the common heard of Fooles, and to laugh at the Disasters, which grew from their Principles of Folly? And, am I at last my self betray'd by a Caprichiousness of Fate to a degree of Contempt, and ridiculousness below the most noted Fops, and celebrated Fooles of the Times?—

sp.speaker: Timothy.
sp.p: What will your Worship be pleas'd I shall do?

sp.speaker: Sir Salom.
sp.p:
Hang your self—[Tim. starts back again. Well; if it must be so, at least the World shall see, that I am none of those tame Fools, that can be the Bawds of their own Infamy, and fairly hold intelligence with those, who are the Authors of their Shame and Dishonour. My revenge shall be
as loud as my disgrace; It shall be Writ in red Letters upon this insolent Robber, and Ravisher of my Affections, and my Honour; and upon that ungrateful young Viper; whom friendless, and indigent, cold, and naked, I took into my warm Bosome, nay more, into my Heart—

sp.speaker: Timothy.
sp.p: I beseech your Worship to dispatch me: Your House is so full of all sorts of Tradesmen, and such a Rabble is got together about the Door (the Drums and Trumpets having proclaim'd a Wedding) that I fear your House and Goods are not safe.

sp.speaker: Sir Salom.
sp.p: There's your dispatch, impertinent Varlet!

sp.speaker: Timothy.
sp.p: Why, Sir! 'tis I: Who d'ee take me for?

sp.speaker: Sir Salom.
sp.p: I am to blame. This extravagance of Passion serves only to make my disgrace more visible: And my Resentment, making a noise in the World, will but sound a Trumpet, to draw more Company in to see the Monster—All things duely weigh'd, Why should I lay the blame on others, when here within me lies my worst Enemy? An obstinate Love has taken possession of my heart, which makes an Ass of my Reason, and forceth me, though I know the Treason, to dote still upon the Traitor. Unjustly I condemn the amorous pursuit of a young Gallant, who is so ignorant of the wrong and affront he does me, that he calls me to Counsell in all his Plots and Contrivance against me! Why do I blame the seduced Ignorance of an Innocent Girle, whose want of knowledge (which causes my Disgrace) is the effect of that Education which I gave her? No: My designs of Revenge are vain, and unjust. I must pull down my Sailes to weather out this storme. My only Course will be, to marry her out of hand: That may open her eyes, to see her Duty; and his, to know the Injury he does me. Heaven! If it may be, make her honest; if not,
sp.l: At least that strength of Patience grant to me,
Which I in other Husbands daily see.

div.stage: Enter Sir Arthur, VVary, Julia, and Roger.

sp.speaker: Wary.
sp.p: VVhat? No Mr. Single appears yet.

sp.speaker: Sir Arthur.
sp.p: Alass, Sir; he dares not shew his Face, when I am here.

sp.speaker: Wary.
sp.p:
Roger, to tell thee truly, my understanding [Apart to Roger.
is quite pos'd, what judgment to frame of this unexpected compliance in my Daughter. Methinks there's still a Mist before my Eyes; for I do not like these sudden Conversions; they favour of Artifice and Design. [Sir Arthur courts Julia. However, I'm resolv'd to drive it as farr as 'twill go: And therefore I'le immediately give directions to my Lawyer for drawing up the Marriage-VVritings. But, you must stay here, that in case Mr. Single comes, you may observe the passages between them.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: I warrant you, Sir; I'le give you an account to a tittle of what's said, or done.

sp.speaker: Wary.
sp.p: Sir Arthur, my business calls me away in order to your Service: But, I leave you in good company. And, Daughter, I expect from you, that when Mr. Single comes, you should give him such a Dismission, as that neither you, nor I, may be any more importun'd by him.

sp.speaker: Iulia.
sp.p: Sir Arthur, I must confess, y' ave already given me abundant proof of your VVit; but, in regard I would fain have a thorough Veneration for him, I am to obey during life, Pray afford me some testimony of your Valour too: For that (you know) is as necessary to protect, as VVit is to govern the Subject.

sp.speaker: Sir Arthur.
sp.p: Valour, Madam? why that's the only fault I am guilty of: I'm too rash. I vow, Madam, my courage is so fierce and outragious, when I let it loose, that I dare not stir abroad, nor meet any body, till I have first chain'd it up, like a curst Masty-dog, for fear of doing mischief.

sp.speaker: Iulia.
sp.p: Good Sir, for my satisfaction unchain it now a little: Here's no body in the way, that can take any hurt, but Roger there; and, if you'l venter your Dog, I'le venter my Fathers Devil.

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: O sweet Lady! for your own dear sake, I would not do it for a World. Alass, Madam, it flies at all, when 'tis loose, without any distinction of Persons; and where it layes hold, it worryes.

sp.speaker: Iulia.
sp.p: O terrible!—But look'ee; The Gentleman's come at last.—What? Am I grown so out of Credit with you, that when I send my mind by a person so worthy of belief, as Sir Arthur Addel, both my Message, and Messenger are to be slighted?

sp.speaker: Single.
sp.p: Madam, in common Justice no man is allow'd for good Evidence, when he speaks in his own Cause.

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: apart to Iulia. Take him up short: Don't let him shew his Wit: He has a smooth Tongue of his own, and will draw you in.

sp.speaker: Iulia.
sp.p: I'm come to see, whether I at least may obtain the favour of your belief.

sp.speaker: Single.
sp.p: I hope, I shall have no cause given me to think you untrue; and then I must believe you.

sp.speaker: Sir Arthur.
sp.p: O Madam; you give him too much head—

sp.speaker: Iulia.
sp.p: Know then, that Sir Arthur was a person sent, and authoriz'd by me; and all that he told you, is true concerning your Better, and his Admission.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: O, well said, sweet young Lady! How my Master's heart will be over-joy'd at it!

sp.speaker: Sir Arthur.
sp.p: Is it I that am to be blam'd now?—

sp.speaker: Single.
sp.p: Madam, I submit: For there's no Appeal for him, whom you condemn.

sp.speaker: Sir Arthur.
sp.p: I say still, Have a care of him—

sp.speaker: Iulia.
sp.p: Come, Sir; stand before me. What Woman can do less, that looks upon Sir Arthur Addel, then yield her self up to so fair an Estate, so comely a Person, such a graceful carriage, so excellent a Witt, such modesty in using it, such invincible Courage—

sp.speaker: Sir Arthur.
sp.p: O Madam, such truths are not to be spoke before my face.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: I'm glad she likes him so well: But did she know all.

sp.speaker: Iulia.
sp.p: Now, Sir; What have you to say in your own behalf, to counter-ballance the perfections of such a Competitour?

sp.speaker: Single.
sp.p: Madam, I am nothing, but what you please to make me.

sp.speaker: Iulia.
sp.p: I would make you understand your self and me; and that I am a person worthy of belief: nor shall all the perswasisions of the World ever seduce me from a well taken resolution.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: You say right, Madam; especially when your Father directs, and commands it.

sp.speaker: Iulia.
sp.p: Especially, when my Father provides a Person every way so qualify'd for a Husband, as the famous Sir Arthur Addel.

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: I vow, Madam, you ravish me. Shall we be Marry'd to night?

sp.speaker: Single.
sp.p: How ambiguous she is? Was ever man so parted in two between Happiness, and Misery?—

sp.speaker: Iulia.
sp.p: To hold you all no longer in suspence, know, that I have now before my eyes the Objects both of my Scorn, and my Esteem: The one by a just title of desert has possession of my Heart; The other by his bold and rude Addresses, has rais'd a just Aversion in me, and contempt of his person. After this Declaration let me see, which is that impudent Man, who dares continue in my presence?

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: I, let him go: His guilty Conscience makes him fly —But Madam, you forgot your promise of binding him to the Peace: He's a troublesome unruly Fellow.

sp.speaker: Iulia.
sp.p: O, call him again.

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: Mr. Single, Mr. Single; The Lady has something more to say to you—I protest, Sir, this is all her own doing; I had not the least hand in it: you must not be angry with me.

sp.speaker: Iulia.
sp.p:
I have also this command for him of you too, whom I
love, that he shall not make the Pretensions of his Rival, any ground of a difference or quarrel.

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: Madam, your Commands shall bind my hands: Though Rivalship be a hard thing to disgest.

sp.speaker: Iulia.
sp.p: Mr. Single, Y'ave now your liberty to retire.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: And, pray Sir, let's see you here no more: It is my old Master's express command as well as my young Mistresse's here.

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: If he comes again, your Order, Madam, for a Cessation of Armes must cease, become void, and of no effect.

sp.speaker: Iulia.
sp.p: I hope, Sir Arthur, he will be so discreet, as not to put you upon desperat courses: But, should the worst happen, 'tis but unchaining your Masty Dogg.

sp.speaker: Sir Arthur.
sp.p: If he makes me do so, he shall ee'n answer himself for all the Mischief that's done.

sp.speaker: Iulia.
sp.p: And so he may, without holding up his hand at the Barr. But, Sir Arthur, the freshness of the Evening warnes me to retire: I know, you'l Gallant me to my Lodging.

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: O yes, Madam—Poor thing! she can't live a moment without me.

div.stage: Enter Peregreen, and Woodlands Man in riding apparel.

sp.speaker: Pereg.
sp.p: But, Art thou sure my Father will be here to night?

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Yes, Sir. He comes in company with one Mr.— ('Faith, Sir, I've forgot his name) a rich Merchant, newly arriv'd from the Indies: And, he sent me before to find you out, that he might not fail to speak with you about some very earnest business, as soon as he came to Town.

sp.speaker: Pereg.
sp.p: What should this business be?

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: I believe, Sir, I can tell you something of it, by what I have over-heard.

sp.speaker: Pereg.
sp.p: Prethy what is't?

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p:
Your Worship then must promise to keep my Counsel: otherwise I shall gain a great deal of ill will with
my old Master, first for over-hearing, and then revealing his private Discourses.

sp.speaker: Pereg.
sp.p: Take my word for thy Security.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: That I will for all I'm worth: And, to tell you truly, Sir, I did ee'n long to be the first, that should bring you this good Newes.

sp.speaker: Pereg.
sp.p: Good News? Of what?

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Of being Marry'd out of hand to a young Lady, who, (they say) is vastly rich, and hugely handsome.

sp.speaker: Pereg.
sp.p: And do'st thou call this good News? I had rather thou hadst told me, That to Morrow I must have gone to Goale, nay more, to Execution; For in one, a man may hope to be releast from Misery, and the other is an end of it: But, to be Marry'd so soon, and having newly tasted Liberty, to have it snatcht away from me for ever, is more then I can suffer. No: My Father must excuse me; All other things he may do of himself without me; but, Marriage is a Work, which I must do, not he.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: I hope, Sir, you are not in earnest; For, by all that I can perceive, my Master's heart is so set upon this business—

sp.speaker: Pereg.
sp.p: Well, well; You may go rest your self after your Journy.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: But, Where shall I find you, Sir, when your Father's come?

sp.speaker: Pereg.
sp.p: Either here, or under the Arches in Covent-Garden. [Exit Servant. Dear Single, Fortune has at last decreed, as we are joyn'd in Friendship, to joyn us in Adversity.

sp.speaker: Single.
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Pereg.
sp.p: I have told you many passages of Love between Betty and me; But, I never fully confess'd to you, how deep the impression was she has made upon my heart. Ah Single! she's the very same thing in every respect to me, that the fair Iulia is to you.

sp.speaker: Single.
sp.p: If this declaration of Love be in earnest, I doubt y'are past the Cure of Reason: Otherwise, I should endeavour to disswade my dear Peregreen from a Passion (if it tend to Marriage) every way so unequal to him.

sp.speaker: Pereg.
sp.p: Ar't thou a Lover thy self, and, Can'st thou talke of inequality in Love.

sp.speaker: Single.
sp.p: I've done; You shall hear no more from me: But, pray, give me leave to be sorry.

sp.speaker: Pereg.
sp.p: You misplace your Sorrow; 'Tis not here that I want it: But, what I now shall tell you, will too justly deserve the compassion of a Friend. Whil'st my Affections are thus unalterably preingag'd, just now my Father comes to Town with a positive determination (as I'm inform'd) of matching me to one of his own providing, whose Person, and Fortune (they say) are such, as to render my disobedience to him unexcusable in the Eyes of the World. Judge then in what condition I am: Uncertain of my Love; for, she's in the hands of my Enemy, her Goaler Evans; And only certain of my Father's just indignation.

sp.speaker: Single.
sp.p: Methinks, your Passion for Betty in so short a time should not have taken such deep roots, but that another might be planted in the roome on't, when a Fortune is offer'd by your Father, so much above her in quality and Estate, and perhaps not inferiour in Beauty.

sp.speaker: Pereg.
sp.p: Deal more justly with a Friend: Is it in your power not to love Iulia? Nor is it more in mine to relinquish Betty. No; whatever befalls me; I'm resolv'd this very night to get her into my possession, and then Marry her: Which being done, I shall endeavour to obtain my Fathers Pardon, for what I could not gain his Consent.

sp.speaker: Single.
sp.p: Well, Sir; since I cannot serve you with my Counsell, at least I offer you my Person, to assist you in the execution of your design.

sp.speaker: Pereg.
sp.p:
No (dear Single;) I know your own occasions of a like nature require your whole attendance: Besides, I look upon your Father, as a more proper Instrument for me in this Work. He's already acquainted with it; and has promis'd secrecy; and his Person (being a Man of years) appearing at
Bettys Lodging, will be less subject to the suspition of old Evans. Moreover, by employing him, I hope to get a sight of his intended Bride; For, in all my own Distractions, I cannot be unmindfull of your Concernes.

sp.speaker: Single.
sp.p: Your Generosity may teach the World new Lessons of Friendship, whilst even in your own Distress you continue such care for me: Thanks to my Stars, my heart is now at some ease concerning Iulia's constancy: I confess, she frighted me at first with that very Vizard, which I bid her put on; But since, through that Disguise, she has artificially cast such beams of Comfort on me, as have reviv'd my drooping Spirits.

sp.speaker: Pereg.
sp.p: May Fortune continue her smiles upon you. Farewell; I must to your Father about my business.

sp.speaker: Single.
sp.p: And I must find out Sir Arthur, to renew a strict League of Amity with him. May we both prosper!

div.stage: Enter Sir Salomon, and Mrs. Betty.

sp.speaker: Sir Salom.
sp.p: Betty, Have you said your Prayers to day?

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: O yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Salom.
sp.p: And, D'ee know what 'tis to die?

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: To die? I remember I saw one of my Nurses Daughters die in the Country.

sp.speaker: Sir Salom.
sp.p: And, How did you like it?

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: O, very ill: She was a pretty Girle before; but, when she was dead, I was afraid to look upon her.

sp.speaker: Sir Salom.
sp.p: Betty, you must die; and die presently.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: No sure, Sir; For I'm as well, as ever I was in my life.

sp.speaker: Sir Salom.
sp.p: How unconcernedly she answers?—apart.—I say again, within this quarter of an hour you must die.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Indeed, Sir, you fright me; and yet I can't see any danger of death.

sp.speaker: Sir Salom.
sp.p:
Wicked Girle! Look upon thy Treason against thy Lord, and Master; thy Ingratitude to thy Benefactor; thy falseness to him, that must be thy Husband: Remember the Letter thou drop'st to day in the Street; and then look upon
me, and tell me, Do'st thou see no danger of death?—What, Are you dumb?—Why don't you answer? you can't speak to me; but you can write to your lewd Gallant?

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: You put me in such a fright, that I am not able to speak.

sp.speaker: Sir Salom.
sp.p: Hussee, you were not afraid to break my Commands, to betray me, to be strumpeted by a wild young Fellow: In all Mischief y'are bold enough; but, when you are to hear your faults, and to answer for your Crimes, then your Fears come upon you!

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: I can't speak for my life, when you look so terribly upon me: look but as you use to do, and I'le answer you any thing.

sp.speaker: Sir Salom.
sp.p: How in spight of my teeth she breaks the force of my Anger, and disarmes it with her softness!—Tell me then, Why did you write that Letter, after I had forbid you all Communication with him?

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: I writ it, because it goes against my Nature to hurt any body; And, since you would needs have me throw that great Stone at him, I could not chuse but let him know, I did it against my will.

sp.speaker: Sir Salom.
sp.p: O, how tender you are in hurting him! whilst at the same time you make nothink of breaking my heart, destroying my happiness, ruining my Reputation, who have been a Nurse, a Father, and would have been a Husband to thee.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Indeed I'm beholding to you for your care of me; And, when I'm able, I'le satisfie you for it.

sp.speaker: Sir Salom.
sp.p: Satisfie me? How the Gipsy word's it! How canst thou satisfie me for all the good I have done to thee, and all the mischief thou hast done to me?

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: God forbid I should do you any mischief: I know of none I have done you.

sp.speaker: Sir Salom.
sp.p:
What Devil has taught thee to sin thus without Remorse? Thy Ignorance cannot excuse thee: For, Have I not daily instructed thee for two years together in thy Obedience, and duty of a Wife? Have I not hourly inculcated into thee, That thou ought'st not so much as to look upon a young
Man; and that thou wert born and made to no other end, but to love me?

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Truly, Sir, I love you as well as I can: And, if I love you no better, 'tis not my fault; you should make your self more lovely.

sp.speaker: Sir Salom.
sp.p: How innocently she stabb's me with her [apart. Answers! No, Gipsy; you can love well enough when y'ave a mind to't, and where you should not: You can Love an impudent Ravisher, who comes to defloure thee, and leave thee a forlorn, prostituted thing, abandon'd to Beggery, and Shame; Him thou canst love: But me, who have rais'd thee from nothing, bred thee as my Child, made thee Mistress both of my Heart and Fortune; me thou canst not love: I (forsooth) must make my self more Lovely.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: What would you ha' me do? I'le do any thing I can, to give you content.

sp.speaker: Sir Salom.
sp.p: Then I command you to renounce all manner of kindness to this bold Assaulter of your Honour, and mine, and never more to see him, nor so much as think upon him.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: That's impossible for me to do: For, now I know him, I must love him, and see him too, when I may.

sp.speaker: Sir Salom.
sp.p: O impudence! to tell me this to my face? Had she been bred in the most famous Schools of Iniquity? Had she been Prentice all her life to the ablest She-Professors of the Trade? Could she have own'd her Transgression with a more daring Confidence? Since thou art so impenitent, and hardned in thy Sin, expect no Mercy—Behold this. [He draws his Sword. Art thou not affraid of my Anger? I hope, now th'art to die, thou'lt repent thee of thy Sins; and (above all) of thy abominable Love of this wicked Man who has so bewitch'd thee.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Sure you won't kill me: But, if you should, I must not leave the World with a Lie in my Mouth, and say, I don't Love this young Man: For indeed I can't chuse but love him. And, I think, it is no Sin, when I can't help it.

sp.speaker: Sir Salom.
sp.p:
How she argues the Case! Where has she learn't this Cunning, and this undauntedness? Ah! she holds intelligence with my heart, and knows the power she has there, which grows stronger and stronger upon me, in spight of all her neglect
to me, and Love to my Rival—Here, Betty; Do you take this Sword: Take it, and kill me. For all the care I have had of thee, for all that I have done, and meant to do for thee (since thou wilt not love me) I ask thee no other reward.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Indeed, Sir, I would not kill you, though 'twere to save my own life: And I'le endeavour to love you as well as ever I can.

sp.speaker: Sir Salom.
sp.p: Nay, unless you'l love me better then that young Man, I must die.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: No, pray don't: What are you the worse, because I love him? You shant lose a Farthing by it. To content you, I should be glad with all my heart I had never seen him, and did not love him: But, now 'tis done, who can help it?

sp.speaker: Sir Salom.
sp.p: How immovable she is! Neither Threats, nor Kindness work upon her. Well, Marry her I will; and take my venture—Betty, notwithstanding all your unkindness, I'le be as good as my word, and Marry you.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Marry me? To whom?

sp.speaker: Sir Salom.
sp.p: Ah, cruel Girle! Why do'st thou stab me with such a question? Love me, or love me not, I'le be your Husband to morrow.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Indeed, Sir, that's very short warning.

sp.speaker: Sir Salom.
sp.p: No more words: I'le have it so. When thou see'st the Bravery, and fine things I've prepar'd for thee, thou'lt be of a better mind.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: If it must be so, I can't help it.

sp.speaker: Sir Salom.
sp.p: Come, get you in; and pray to Heaven, that thou may'st be sensible of the happiness I intend thee.

div.stage: Sir Salomon goes off the Stage the other way, and at the Door meets Peregreen coming in.

sp.speaker: Pereg.
sp.p: Sir Salomon, I have been in despair for want of seeing you; For you are my good Angel—

sp.speaker: Sir Salom.
sp.p: And you my Devil—

sp.speaker: Pereg.
sp.p:
That must direct and assist me, and crown all your
past favours with the most important kindness that I am capable of receiving.

sp.speaker: Sir Salom.
sp.p: What is't, Sir?

sp.speaker: Pereg.
sp.p: Only to deliver this Letter safely to my Betty: On her receipt of it depends no less, then the happiness of my life. I dare not approach the House my self by day-light, because the Servants know me, who are now turn'd of old Evans his Party: Nor can I put my concerns in such trusty hands as yours.

sp.speaker: Sir Salom.
sp.p: Does it require haste in the delivery?

sp.speaker: Pereg.
sp.p: O, by all means: The Lodging is close by; 'Tis a Corner House, with a Belcony, that looks into the Fields here, next to Swan-Ally: You may see the House from hence. Now, Sir, the way to deliver it, that neither old Evans, nor his Houshold-Spies may see it, is to tie it to something, and then toss it up into the Belcony: By the manner of the conveyance Betty will presently know whence it comes, and how to behave her self: And, this is the proper time of doing it; For, at this hour she alwayes comes out in the Belcony, to take a little fresh Air of the Evening; It being all the liberty allow'd her by her Jaylor.

sp.speaker: Sir Salom.
sp.p: Well, Sir; This is all.

sp.speaker: Pereg.
sp.p: It imports me likewise, that you should know the business. My passion for Betty is now come to that height, that I'm resolv'd instantly to Marry her. But (most unfortunately to my Designs) my Father comes this night to Town; and with a resolution (as I am certainly inform'd) to strike up a Bargain of Marriage for me of his own driving. In these Streights I have no expedient left to prevent his purpose, and execute my own, but to get possession of Betty, and Marry her out of hand. Though my Fathers present dissatisfaction may be great, yet, I hope, time will mollifie him; And I doubt not but your good Offices will much contribute towards it.

sp.speaker: Sir Salom.
sp.p: You may be sure of me. But, when d'ee purpose to get possession of your Mistriss?

sp.speaker: Pereg.
sp.p: This very Night, as soon as 'tis dark; for, by that time Evans alwayes retires to his own quarters.

sp.speaker: Sir Salom.
sp.p: But, What place of security have you to lodge her in, when y'ave brought her off?

sp.speaker: Pereg.
sp.p: There lies my greatest difficulty; And, were it not too bold a Petition, I should think no place so safe and honourable for her reception, as your house, only for a day or two, till I've made her my Wife: But, Sir, I have trespass'd already too farr upon your generosity, and dare transgress no farther.

sp.speaker: Sir Salom.
sp.p: O Sir, your modesty does me wrong. To mistrust the kindness of a Friend, is the greatest sin in Friendship. Bring her when you will, you shall find, that my House is her Home.

sp.speaker: Pereg.
sp.p: You surpass all Men living in the noble Art of obliging a Friend. But upon reflection, since y'are to be Marry'd your self to morrow, I fear her coming at such a time may prove unseasonable.

sp.speaker: Sir Salom.
sp.p: So farr from it, that I'm resolv'd not to be Marry'd without her.

sp.speaker: Pereg.
sp.p: You are generous to that excess, that you leave me not a possibility of being grateful. And now, Sir, I have nothing more to begg of you, but the Honour of kissing your Ladies hands before her Marriage; that I may obtain an early place in her favour, by letting her know what my Obligations are to you.

sp.speaker: Sir Salom.
sp.p: Matters of Complement and Curiosity require no haste: But, since you so much desire it, I give you my word, That, when you bring Mrs. Betty to me, you shall then see my Wife.

sp.speaker: Pereg.
sp.p: You make me happy every way, except in this, that I owe you more then I am worth; And am forc'd, like other Banckrupts, to compound my Debts, begging you to accept those small Services I can pay, in lieu of the vast Summ that's due.

sp.speaker: Sir Salom.
sp.p: O, Sir, you mistake in the Account between us: I am yet in your Arrears, which I shall endeavour to discharge out of hand, by serving you in this business concerning Mrs. Betty, as I ought.

sp.speaker: Pereg.
sp.p: Dear Sir Salomon, Farewell; And good luck attend you.

sp.speaker: Sir Salom.
sp.l: Doubt not, young Man, I'le serve you as I ought;
As Men serve Vermine, that in Traps are caught.

div.head: The Fifth Act.

sp.speaker: Timothy.
sp.p: WHat? Kick your Steward? The Supreme Head of the Family under your Worship? 'Tis such an Affront done to my Office, as I cannot in honour put up: Therefore, as I said before, here are my Keyes, and here are my Accounts; and so I take my leave.

sp.speaker: Sir Salom.
sp.p: Nay, prethy, Timothy, be pacify'd: Good-natur'd Men (thou know'st) are subject to Passion.

sp.speaker: Timot.
sp.p: But Stewards, Sir, are not subject to be kick't. Shew me but one President for it amongst all those of my Profession, and I'le be bound to be your Worships Football as long as I live.

sp.speaker: Sir Salom.
sp.p: Indeed the Case is extraordinary; And so was the Cause; and so shall the Satisfaction be: For, Timothy, I'le give thee in amends a Childes Life in thy Copy-hold.

sp.speaker: Timot.
sp.p: Well, Sir; since 'tis your seeking, I accept of the Reparation —Sir, I have two or three Children more yet unprovided for; if your Worship will be pleas'd to kick them into Livings too, I stand ready to have their Fines laid upon me.

sp.speaker: Sir Salom.
sp.p:
So, so; I'm glad wee're friends again. Now call in my Family; For, I have something of consequence, which I must propound to you
Tim. whistles, and the Servants enter. all. Come forwards: If any body here thinks his Work too much, or his Wages too little, or his Lodging and Fare too hard; Timothy, I order you to give him all reasonable satisfaction.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: God bless your Worship.

sp.speaker: Sir Salom.
sp.p: And I doubt not on your parts, but y'are all ready to serve my Person, and vindicate my Honour, as occasion shall require.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Our Lives are at your Service.

sp.speaker: Sir Salom.
sp.p: Know then, that this very moment I am actually assaulted by an insolent young Fellow, who, to night Plots no less Mischief, then to Ravish my Bride.

sp.speaker: Timot.
sp.p: What manner of death would your Worship have him die?

sp.speaker: Sir Salom.
Timot.
sp.p: Shew us but the Man, and your Worship shall see, that we are as able to serve you in chastising your Enemies, as entertaining your Friends.

sp.speaker: W. Serv.
sp.p: Pray, Gentlemen, can you direct me to the Lodging of Sir Salomon Single?

sp.speaker: Timot.
sp.p: Friend, there's Sir Salomon himself.

sp.speaker: W. Serv.
sp.p: Squire Woodland, my Master, commanded me to let you know, that he is newly come to Town upon some business, in which your Worship is concern'd; and desires, he may speak with you before you go to bed.

sp.speaker: Sir Salom.
sp.p: Friend, tell thy Master, that, if I can possibly, I'le waite upon him: Where's his Lodging?

sp.speaker: W. Serv.
sp.p: At a Barbers, next doore to the Fleece-Tavern in Southampton-Buildings.

sp.speaker: Sir Salom.
sp.p: Very well—apart—In what a seasonable hour this old Man's come to Town, to see the Iniquity of his Son chastis'd? However, my person shall not appear upon the Stage in this Tragedy; I'le only prompt behind the Curtain.

sp.speaker: W. Serv.
sp.p: Where shall I find my young Master now, the Lord knows. This was one of the places he appointed—

div.stage: Enter Single, and Peregreen looking upon his Watch.

sp.speaker: Pereg.
sp.p: The time draws near; yet, didst thou know (Single) with what panting expectation I long to be possest of my Treasure, thou wouldst pity the Torment, which each Moment brings me, by interposing it self between me and my Happiness.

sp.speaker: W. Serv.
sp.p: O, Sir; well met! My old Master's newly come to Town, and by all means must speak with you instantly.

sp.speaker: Pereg.
sp.p: Peace, Screech-Owl! I think that Fellow was born to bring me ill Newes.

sp.speaker: W. Serv.
sp.p: In troth, Sir, I think so too: For, if to Marry a rich handsome Lady, and to see your Father after so long an absence, be ill Newes, I'm sure I can bring you none that's good.

sp.speaker: Pereg.
sp.p: Ah, Single! What shall I do? I must not disappoint Betty; and I should not neglect my Father.

sp.speaker: Single.
sp.p: None can tell you better, then I, what the danger is of disgusting a Father, though innocently: And yet I'm too much a Lover my self to advise a breach of promise with your Mistriss. To satisfie both, you must deferr your going to Betty for an hour, or thereabouts. Your Father must needs be weary after his Journy; and cannot hold you long: And, that she may not think her self disappointed by you, write a note to her, to let her know the occasion.

sp.speaker: Pereg.
sp.p: But, Who shall deliver it?

sp.speaker: Single.
sp.p: Had not I a private summons from Iulia to meet her just at this time, I'de be your Man: But, you may send your Father's Servant there.

sp.speaker: Pereg.
sp.p: Send him? He scarce knows the Town by day; much less by night.
What makes this Fool come to disturb us now?

sp.speaker: Single.
sp.p:
O, pray bear with him: By a special command from Iulia I am now enter'd into a strict League of Amity with him. Faith, ee'n send him with the Note; and you'l do me a particular
kindness in it; for otherwise, hee'l stick upon me like a Burr, and disappoint my meeting with Iulia.

sp.speaker: Pereg.
sp.p: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Sir Arthur.
sp.p: Why, Gentleman, Where have you been? These two long houres I have done nothing but hunt after you.

sp.speaker: Single.
sp.p: Well, Sir, For what?

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.l: For we are but brittle Clay,
Then let's he Merry whil'st we may.

sp.speaker: Single.
sp.p: O brave Arthur of Bradly! The Motion's good in it self, but not seas'nable for us at this time; for, we have business, in which you must do a Friends part.

sp.speaker: Sir Arthur.
sp.p: Thou knowst (Man) I love Business: What is't? Quickly.

sp.speaker: Single.
Sir Arthur.
sp.p: Come, give it me; I long to be in Action.

sp.speaker: Pereg.
sp.p: You shall have it immediately.

sp.speaker: Sir Arthur.
sp.p: Faith. Single, never let's break good company▪ Prethy, come along with me, when I deliver this Note.

sp.speaker: Single.
sp.p: Could I have gone, you should not have had the trouble on't; But, I am preingag'd.

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: Prethy, Where?

sp.speaker: Single.
sp.p: Why—to tell you, as a Friend, I have an appointment just now to receive a little Mony; and, that's a business (you know) I must not neglect.

sp.speaker: Sir Arthur.
sp.p: Hang Mony: A Friends Company is better then it, at any time.

sp.speaker: Single.
sp.p: Why, there's the difference between us two now: You have too much Mony, and want Company; and I have too much Company, and want Mony.

sp.speaker: Pereg.
sp.p: Well, Gentlemen, I have done. Sir Arthur, Have you a Watch about you?

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: No, Sir, not I.

sp.speaker: Pereg.
sp.p: Here, take mine; and precisely at half an hour past eight, deliver this Note to a young Lady at the Corner house that has a Belcony, which looks into Holborn-Fields, next to Swan-Ally.

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: I know the place.

sp.speaker: Pereg.
sp.p: But you must knock gently at the back-door of the Garden, to'rds the Fields; and, when she appears, give her the Note, and tell her, He who sent it, will be with her about an hour hence, or sooner, if he can.

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: Take no further care; your business shall be punctually done.

sp.speaker: Pereg.
sp.p: Y'are an obliging person, Sir Arthur—Come, Harry; Now I am for my Father.

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: But hark'ee, Mr. Single; Did not you tell me, that this Peregreen was one of my Rivals? I vow now (upon better consideration) Why should I do such a kindness for an Enemy? for ought that I know, there may be some trick in't.

sp.speaker: Single.
sp.p: 'Tis true, I did tell you, that he was then newly enter'd the List of your Rivalls: But now (take my word for't) he's so farr from it, that he's engag'd elsewhere: And this kindness which you are now to do for him, relates to his new Amour.

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p:
Nay, I'le take your word for't— Enter Mr. Wary.
O, Father-in-Law?

sp.speaker: Single.
sp.p: Sir Arthur, farewell.

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: God buy, Sir.

sp.speaker: Wary.
sp.p: I'm glad I've found you at last; for, I sent my Man all the Town over to look you.

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: And now you have me, What have you to say to me?

sp.speaker: Wary.
sp.p: You must needs come away immediately with me to my Lawyers Chamber.

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: Excuse me, Sir; I must not.

sp.speaker: Wary.
sp.p: I have appointed a Meeting about the Marriage Writings, and both our Counsell are already there.

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: There let 'em waite; I'le pay 'em by the hour.

sp.speaker: Wary.
sp.p: I thought, Sir, you had been more in haste, and more pressing in matters that concern your affection to my Daughter.

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: Nay, take it not ill, good Sir: your Daughter and I understand one another very well; we don't stand upon such Punctillio's.

sp.speaker: Wary.
sp.p: I am affraid, she understands you but too well.

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: Let me see—VVhat a Clock is't now? Some half an hour hence I can be there; till then Mr. Lawyer must have patience.

sp.speaker: Wary.
sp.p: VVell, Sir, if it must be so, then I'le go before: But first, pray, Sir, let me give you a little good advice.

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: You need not, Sir; we shall go to Counsell within this half hour.

sp.speaker: Wary.
sp.p: 'Tis the Advise of a Friend, not of a Lawyer, that I would give you. I perceive, that you are very much in the company of this Mr. Single, who, in my judgment, is, for several respects, a person very unfit and dangerous for you to converse with: First, he has a great deal of Wit, and no Meanes—

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: Which is to say, I have a great deal of Means, and no Wit—Go on, Sir.

sp.speaker: Wary.
sp.p: Not so neither. In the next place, he is, or has been your Rivall to'rds my Daughter: Now judge you, VVhat Friendship you can expect from an indigent Man, whom you have dispossest of all hopes to raise his sunck Fortune?

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: Hark'ee, Sir, You are Mrs. Iulia's Father, Are you not?

sp.speaker: Wary.
sp.p: Yes, Sir. VVhat makes you aske such a Question?

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: 'Tis well you are: Otherwise I should be bold to tell you, That I'm already provided of a wiser Governor then your Worship, by name, Sir Arthur Addel. S'liddikins, I have liv'd to a fair Age, if every old Man must take upon him to be my Tutour.

sp.speaker: Wary.
sp.p: I'm sorry my good Will's lost upon you. However, pray fail not to come according to your promise.

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p:
No, no— [He looks in the Watch. Gods so; whilst I have been talking idely with this old Fellow, I have almost slipt the time of my business—VVhere shall I find this Lodging now?—I was but an Ass (to say the truth) for undertaking this Owle-light employment—How dark 'tis grown all of a sudden?—Let me see; This must be the House. Sir Arthur knocks, and Sir Salomon's Men rush forth, and lay hold of him.
Enter Timothy and Servants. Oh! oh!

sp.speaker: Tim▪
sp.p: Suffer patiently; y'had best: If you make a Noise, you die for't.

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: Quickly, quickly; pray take my Mony and my Cloaths, and use me gently.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: If he speaks one word more, cut his Throat—No, Sir; your Punishment must not be Pecuniary, but Corporal: your Crime is Letchery; and, the Body must suffer for the Sins of the Flesh.

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: Murder! murder! murder!

div.stage: He sprawles like a dying Man, and then streches out as dead.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: VVhat? Is he dead?

sp.speaker: 1. Serv.
sp.p: Some unlucky blow has hit him under the Eare.

sp.speaker: 2. Serv.
sp.p: 'Pox take him for a Chicken-hearted Fellow, to die so soon.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Unfortunate men that we are! VVhat will become of us?

sp.speaker: 3. Serv.
sp.p: The Gallows take the bindmost, I cry.

div.stage: The Third Man runs away, and all the rest follow.
Ralph peeps out of Mrs. Bettys Lodgings twice, or thrice, Sir Salomon comes forth.

sp.speaker: Sir Salom.
sp.p:
VVhat's the Matter?—The Rogues have
undone me by thus over-doing their Work! This will cover me with shame, and infamy, and bring in question my Life, and Estate! What shall I do? Whither shall I fly—I hear the noise of Justice—

sp.speaker: 1. Watch-man.
sp.p: I'm sure I heard a cry of Murder—Look Neighbour, here has been Mischief done. The Man is dead.

sp.speaker: 2. Watch-man.
sp.p: Come, let's carry him off.

sp.speaker: Constable.
sp.p: No, no; let's first call the Coroner; 'Tis dangerous medling, till he has sate upon the dead Body; after that, he may be buried out of the way.

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: How? Carry me off, and Bury me, said they? I'le shew' em a trick worth two on't. He run's to the end of the Stage, and then turus back. 'Tis better dying of ones own accord, as I have done, then by compulsion of others, as I must have done.

div.stage: Ralph peeps first, and then enters.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: What? all run away? And the dead Man too? Then I'le 'een run too for Company.

div.stage: Enter Betty, with a Basket in her hand, and Allice.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: What was this Noise, and out-cry, which we heard? Pray God there be no hurt done.

sp.speaker: Allice.
sp.p: Yes, but there is hurt done; For, I heard 'em say, he was kill'd?

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Kill'd? Tell me quickly, Who's kill'd?

sp.speaker: Allice.
sp.p: As long as you are alive, What need you trouble your self?

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Thou naughty Wench; I could find in my heart to beate thee: I'ell me, I say, VVho was kill'd?

sp.speaker: Allice.
sp.p: I did not see him; but, I believe, 'tis the young Man that us'd to come hither, by what I could over-hear.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: VVhere are the Rogues that did it? I'le kill 'em with my own hands; or, if I can't, I'le kill my self. Help me, Allice, to find them out.

sp.speaker: Allice.
sp.p: Nay, Pray Mistriss, have patience.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: I will not have patience: I'le either be reveng'd on them, or on her, for whose sake he was kill'd.

sp.speaker: Allice.
sp.p: VVhy Mistriss; now I think on't, if any body had been kill'd, we should have seen him lie here: but, here's no sign of any hurt done.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: VVho's there?

sp.speaker: Allice.
sp.p: O, Mistriss, run away: here are more of the Rogues.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Thou Coward! I'le at 'em, and fly in their Faces.

sp.speaker: Pereg.
sp.p: VVhat? Betty?

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Is't you?

sp.speaker: Allice.
sp.p: I Mistriss; 'tis 'een he, whom you thought to be dead.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: O Lord! I was affraid, y'had been kill'd.

sp.speaker: Pereg.
sp.p: No, dear Betty; I was only hinder'd from coming at my hour; And I sent thee word on't—But this is no place for us to stand talking in. Come, Betty; now I have thee in my possession, I'le put thee in a safe place, farr enough out of the reach of thy Jaylor Evans.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: But, VVill you Marry me?

sp.speaker: Pereg.
sp.p: Ah Betty! VVhy art thou so cruel, as to make a doubt on't? I'le rather die, then not Marry thee—VVhat hast thou in thy hand there? give me thy Basket; it troubles thee to carry it.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p:
Then (pray) have a great care on't, and let it not
go out of your hands; for, there is a VVriting in't, which I'm told, is worth me a great deale.

sp.speaker: Pereg.
sp.p: I warrant you; I'le not part from't. Enter Sir Salomon Mufled up in his Cloak. VVhose that?—Sir Salomon?—Most fortunately met, to relieve me in distress! Here, Sir, I have now my Jewel to consign into your hands; Pray have a care of her, as of my Life. I broke away with violence from my Father to look after this Treasure: But, I'm oblig'd to return immediately to him. Pray, lose no time; but lodge her safely in your House: For, I apprehend the pursuit of old Evans. VVithin this hour I hope to be with you. Dear Betty, for a little while farewell.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: VVhat? VVill you leave me so soon?

sp.speaker: Pereg.
sp.p: I'le be with thee again immediately: In the mean time I leave thee in a Friends hands, who will have the same care of thee that I have.

sp.speaker: Sir Salom.
sp.p:
Gipsy, D'ee know me? [Betty skreeks.
Keep in your shrill Notes; or I shall stop your VVind-pipe for you. VVhat? Did your Gallant lie stretcht out upon the floor like a Fox, to run away with the Poultry? Once more I have thee in my hands: Let him snap thee again, and I'le forgive him, and thee too—Come away, quickly, y'had best.

div.stage: [Exit Betty, and Sir Salomon into his own Lodging.
Enter the Constable and Watch with Sir Arthur in Custody.

sp.speaker: Constable.
sp.p: Hold your self contented; VVee'l not part with you so: You'r a very suspitious Person; for immediately after the Fact committed, we found you running away.

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: Pray, Mr. Constable, believe me; Indeed I'm an honest Man.

sp.speaker: Constable.
sp.p: Clear your self before the Justice, and I'm satisfy'd: But, thither you must.

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: Am not I finely serv'd? Now shall I be hang'd for killing my self.

sp.speaker: 2. Watchman.
sp.p: Neighbour, the Rogues, since we were here, have carry'd away the Body.

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: Friend, you are mistaken; The Body carry'd away it self.

sp.speaker: 2. Watchman.
sp.p: How the Man talks? Sure he's Mad.

sp.speaker: 3. Watchman.
sp.p: I, Neighbour, they that shed Man's Blood are commonly so: 'Tis a Judgment upon Murtherers.

sp.speaker: 1. Watchman.
sp.p: To what Justice shall we carry him, Mr. Constable?

sp.speaker: Constable.
sp.p: To Justice Wary; He's nighest at hand.

sp.speaker: 2. Watchman.
sp.p: I, he's as like to get him hang'd, as any Justice upon the Bench.

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: VVhy, Mr. Constable; VVhat d'ee mean to do? Upon my reputation I am the Man that was kill'd.

sp.speaker: 1. Watchman.
sp.p: Away, away with him; he's raving mad: Derick must be his Doctor.

sp.speaker: 2. Watchman.
sp.p: This is the Justice his House.

sp.speaker: Constable.
sp.p: Knock then.

div.stage: Enter a Servant of Mr. VVary's.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: What would you have?

sp.speaker: Constable.
sp.p: We have apprehended a Man here upon suspition of Murder; and we have brought him to be Examin'd and Committed by his Worship.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: That's well: I'le call my Master instantly; He's but a little way off, at Grey's-Inn.

sp.speaker: Constable.
sp.p: Pray make haste.

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: Friend, friend; 'tis I: Don't you know me?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: I know no body, when he's in the hands of Justice. My Master shall be here strait.

div.stage: Enter Single and Julia at the Corner of the Stage.

sp.speaker: Iulia.
sp.p:
I did certainly hear Sir Arthur Addell's voice. Look, where my Knight is in the Constables clutches! Slip you away,
whilst I go see, what the meaning is of this Tragy-Comedy. [Exit Single. Well, Mr. Constable; Who is't, that you have brought hither to my Father?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Madam, A very wicked Man, without doubt: For, here was Murder committed close by; and, presently after we caught him flying away, with as guilty a Countenance as ever I saw: and yet I have seen many in my time.

sp.speaker: Iulia.
sp.p: A very shrew'd presumption indeed.

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: But, Madam, Don't you know me? All this while 'tis I, your Husband that must be, whom these Rogues abuse thus.

sp.speaker: Iulia.
sp.p: I'm the sorrier for't, Sir Arthur; that a Man of your Quality should run himself into such Enormities: I thought, you had not been so bloody. And yet, 'tis no more then what your self have confest formerly to me; that, when your Courage is let loose, like a fierce Mastiff-Dog, it falls upon all that comes in it's way.

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: Nay, but pray, Madam, hear me: Will you mistake the Matter too, like these Clod-pated Rascalls here? I am the very Man, on whose Person all this Murder was committed; for I was set upon by Rogues, that would have kill'd me, but that I prevented 'em—

sp.speaker: Iulia.
sp.p: How? By killing 'em?

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: No, no, Madam; by dying my self; or at least making them believe so: At which the Rogues took such a fright for fear of hanging, that away run they; and away went I: Then come the Clutches of the Parish here, and, according to their usual Custome, seise me, who was the Person assaulted, and suffer the Rogues to make their escape.

sp.speaker: Constable.
sp.p: A very pretty story indeed! No, no; Mr. Iustice, when he comes, won't be fob'd off so.

sp.speaker: Iulia.
sp.p: In troth, Sir Arthur, 'tis so intricate a Case, that I can determine nothing in't, till my Fther comes.

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: Good Madam, make the Slaves release me: I would not for a World be seen in their Company by your Father.

sp.speaker: Iulia.
sp.p:
I vow, Sir, I dare not intrench upon my Fathers Authority: Y'are now in the hands of the Law; and that must
either, quit you, or condemn you—Neighbours, y'had best bring your Prisoner within doors till my Father comes.

sp.speaker: Constable.
sp.p: Yes, Madam. Jogge on, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Arth.
sp.p: Ill-natur'd-woman! I'le pay all thy Scores, when once thou art my Wife.

div.stage: [Exit Sir, Arthur, Julia, and the Watch.

sp.speaker: Pereg.
sp.p: Ah Single! What shall I do? Whil'st I'me happy in the possession of my Mistriss, my Father is so violently bent upon this Match of his own providing, that to oppose him openly in it, would certainly cause as wide a breach in our Family, as is already (unfortunately) in yours.
